holdings.text: It follows therefore that the finding of the Courts below that the appellants party formed an unlawful assembly and that the appellant is constructively liable for the offences under s. 302 and s. 307, Indian Penal Code, in view of s. 149, is correct.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of evidence, it is not possible to say that the Courts below could not have come to the conclusion that there were more than five persons in the appellants party. It follows therefore that the finding of the Courts below that the appellants party formed an unlawful assembly and that the appellant is constructively liable for the offences under s. 302 and s. 307,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence showed witnesses stated 13 persons but named fewer inconsistently; acquittal of some named does not preclude >5 total as not all assailants definitely named; distinguished Dalip Singh.

holdings.text: The second contention that in a free fight each is liable for an individual act cannot be accepted in view of the decision of this Court in Gore Lal v. State of U. P.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention that in a free fight each is liable for an individual act cannot be accepted in view of the decision of this Court in Gore Lal v. State of U. P. 1 . This Court said in that case- In any event, on the finding of the Court of first instance and of the High Court that both the parties had prepared themselves for a free fight and had armed themselves for that purpose,

holdings.reasoning_summary: In pre-planned free fight with arms, parties have common object to cause injuries; liable under s.149 for acts in furtherance irrespective of individual acts or who started.

holdings.text: Even if the finding that there were more than five persons in the appellants party be wrong, we are of opinion that the facts found that the appellant and his companions who were convicted had gone from the village armed and determined to fight, amply justified the conclusion that they had the common intention to attack the other party and to cause such injuries which may result in death.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Armed departure from village for pre-determined fight implies common intention sufficient for s.34 liability for murder and attempt to murder.

holdings.text: The mere fact that Kartar Singh was not connected with the dispute about the plot of land is not sufficient to hold that he could not have formed a common intention with the others, when he went with them armed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Participation armed in group going to fight infers shared intention regardless of personal stake in dispute.

holdings.text: The conviction under s. 302 and s. 307 read with s. 149 can be converted into one under s. 302 and s. 307 read with s. 34, Indian Penal Code.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative basis under common intention sustains conviction even absent unlawful assembly of >5.

precedents.citation: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab  1 ... 1 1954.C.R. 145,150

anchor.surface_text: This is clear from the observations in Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab  1  of this Court Now mistaken identity has never been suggest- ed. The accused are ail men of the same village and the eye-witnesses know them by name. The murder took place in daylight and within a few feet of the two eye-witnesses. The same cannot be said in this case.

precedents.case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Acquittal of named accused when identity is not in doubt precludes inference of additional unidentified members in the unlawful assembly to make it exceed five persons
precedents.cited_holding: Now mistaken identity has never been suggested. The accused are all men of the same village and the eye-witnesses know them by name. The murder took place in daylight and within a few feet of the two eye-witnesses.

precedents.citation: Gore Lal v. State of U. P.  1 ... Criminal Appeal No. 29 of 1950, decided on December 15, 1960

anchor.surface_text: The second contention that in a free fight each is liable for an individual act cannot be accepted in view of the decision of this Court in Gore Lal v. State of U. P.  1 . This Court said in that case- In any event, on the finding of the Court of first instance and of the High Court that both the parties had prepared themselves for a free fight and had armed themselves for that purpose, the question as to who attacks and who defends is wholly immaterial,

precedents.case_name: Gore Lal v. State of U. P.
precedents.cited_proposition: In a pre-concerted free fight where both parties come armed, the issue of who is the aggressor is immaterial and conviction under section 149 IPC is sustainable
precedents.cited_holding: In any event, on the finding of the Court of first instance and of the High Court that both the parties had prepared themselves for a free fight and had armed themselves for that purpose, the question as to who attacks and who defends is wholly immaterial

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the finding of the Courts below that the appellants party formed an unlawful assembly and that the appellant is companystructively liable for the offences under s. 302 and s. 307, Indian Penal Code, in view of s. 149, is companyrect.

outcome.relief_summary: Courts below's finding that appellant's party formed unlawful assembly and appellant constructively liable under s.302/307 r/w s.149 IPC upheld; conviction confirmed (alternatively under s.34 IPC)

anchor.surface_text: The second contention that in a free fight each is liable for an individual act cannot be accepted in view of the decision of this Court in Gore Lal v. State of U. P. 1 . It follows therefore that the finding of the Courts below that the appellants party formed an unlawful assembly and that the appellant is companystructively liable for the offences under s. 302 and s. 307, Indian Penal Code, in view of s. 149, is companyrect.
